Literature Review: The Radical S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) enzyme superfamily represents a fascinating and expansive group of enzymes that catalyze a wide array of biochemical reactions through the generation of radical species. Central to their function is the use of a site-differentiated [4Fe-4S] cluster and SAM to initiate radical reactions, primarily through the liberation of the 5′-deoxyadenosyl (5′-dAdo•) radical. This mechanism of radical initiation is both complex and highly conserved across the superfamily, which boasts over 700,000 unique sequences and continues to grow due to ongoing bioinformatics efforts (Broderick et al., 2014). The diversity of reactions catalyzed by these enzymes is remarkable, ranging from the biosynthesis of complex natural products to the modification of nucleic acids and proteins, all of which are characterized by their high regio- and stereo-specificity (Frey et al., 2008). At the heart of the radical SAM superfamily's catalytic mechanism is the formation of an organometallic intermediate, Ω, which features an Fe–C5′-adenosyl bond. This intermediate is formed through the regioselective reductive cleavage of the SAM S–C5′ bond, a process that is driven by the Jahn–Teller effect, leading to the production of the 5′-dAdo• radical (Booker et al., 2007). The liberation of the free 5′-dAdo• radical, which serves as the catalytically active intermediate, occurs through homolysis of the Fe–C5′ bond. This mechanism bears a striking resemblance to the Co–C5′ bond homolysis observed in B12-dependent enzymes, which were once considered biology's primary radical generators (Banerjee & Ragsdale, 2003). The discovery of the Ω intermediate and its role in radical SAM enzymes has significantly expanded our understanding of biological radical generation and has highlighted the versatility of iron-sulfur clusters in enzyme catalysis (Sofia et al., 2001). Furthermore, the study of radical SAM enzymes has provided insights into the evolution of enzyme mechanisms and the potential for engineering novel biocatalysts (Hanzelmann & Schindelin, 2004). The ability of these enzymes to catalyze such a diverse array of reactions with high specificity is a testament to the elegance and efficiency of their catalytic mechanism, which continues to be a subject of intense research and interest (Wang et al., 2014). As our understanding of the radical SAM superfamily grows, so too does our appreciation for the complexity and ingenuity of biological systems in harnessing radical chemistry for the synthesis and modification of biomolecules (Zhang et al., 2012).
